intro: Olax boiviniana, commonly known as the African olive, is a small evergreen shrub native to southern Africa. It belongs to the family Rhamnaceae and is characterized by its dense, leathery leaves and small, fragrant yellow flowers. The plant produces small, fleshy berries that are an important food source for birds and small mammals. It thrives in well-drained soils and is often found in rocky or coastal habitats. Due to its ornamental value and ecological importance, it is sometimes cultivated in gardens and conservation areas.
